awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  An intelligent mental health care companion for kids
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to proactively identify and resolve mental health issues for children ages 10 - 18 before treatments and consequences become more acute and significantly more costly. This project innovation proposes bringing care to children at the onset of need using chatbot companions tailored deliberately and precisely to each child’s mental healthcare needs. Optionally, a child can be paired with live chat therapists and coaches no matter where the child is — at home, school, or when on their own. The system leverages proven mobile device-accessed Cognitive Behavioral Therapies in tandem with machine learning (ML)-enabled technologies that learn from a variety of interactions with the child to detect and digitally triage their experiences of loneliness, anger, anxiety, and depression and to alert adults when intervention and treatment are deemed necessary. Without appropriate care, these symptoms frequently increase in severity over time and become more difficult to treat.  Intervening early can help slow or halt mental illness, reducing for parents, schools, and society the practical and financial burdens associated with reactive, generalized mental healthcare treatments while nurturing children into happier, healthier adults.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to build a system to determine the nature and severity of a child’s mental health needs through real-time, early detection. Research reveals children face more barriers than adults when obtaining mental healthcare, especially in rural, marginalized, and low-socioeconomic-status communities. Due to a severe shortage of child behavioral health practitioners across the country, children frequently wait up to a decade between the onset of mental health symptoms and treatment. This project seeks to eliminate the delay between when children first experience mental or emotional needs and when they receive appropriate care, ensuring they flourish—not flounder—during those crucial developmental years. Leveraging ML algorithms and proprietary question weighting, the project focuses on: 1) algorithm development to determine the most effective combination of chatbot and live chat counselor engagements to understand a child’s immediate issues and provide resolutions for the child and their parent(s); 2) improvements to ensure the responses are fit for purpose, recognizing and flagging appropriate conversations for human interaction; and 3) refining the frequency and content of notifications; such as, adaptive motivational messages and recommendations to counselors for tailoring interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
ABSTRACT

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide middle schools with an early intervention tool using an intelligent mental health care companion. A national emergency in youth mental health was declared in 2021 by the U.S. Surgeon General. But the increased demand for mental health services combined with a lack of qualified professionals, costs, and the time it takes to find a clinician makes accessing care a challenge for most U.S. families.

reThinkIt!'s Phase I research sought to use its disruptive technology to help schools deal with mental health issues that are causing physical illness, absenteeism, and unproductive learning time and to move youth mental health from where it is today at epidemic proportions to help schools manage the ongoing issues that students face daily.

Through Minty, our intelligent chatbot, reThinkIt! facilitates a more effective way to communicate, impacting a broader segment of society. Untreated mental illness in children poses grave consequences, including suicide, stress, anxiety, depression, academic decline, and unemployment. Mental health challenges alone will cost the global economy $16 trillion from 2020-2030 accounting for more than half of the global economic burden of disease over the next 20 years...more than cancer, diabetes, and chronic respiratory diseases combined.

The R&D not only improved upon the existing reThinkIt! beta but added some significant components for improved accessibility, affordability, and effectiveness: (1) researched and developed additional algorithms to coordinate conversations between Minty and students as well as counselors and teachers; (2) developed a machine learning engine to insure the Ai responses are fit for purpose and alert school personnel to danger when students report critical issues; and (3) validated improvements are working through school-based research. reThinkIt! underwent efficacy testing and customer discovery from middle school principals, assistant principals, counselors, in-school suspension coordinators, teachers and students to confirm the improvements are acceptable with current discipline management practices.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

reThinkIt! is a groundbreaking innovation using Minty, an intelligent chatbot companion, LiveChat counselors, and a novel What'sUp? assessment. This evidence-based "early detection" mental health assessment helps ages 10-14 better process difficult emotions, understand their own behaviors, and navigate the behaviors of others. We learned more about the effects of Covid-19 on mental well-being in schools and have proposed new features and technologies in Phase II to address key concerns from schools to enable them to effectively address mental health with early disciplinary intervention while supporting the well-being of staff and students.

Like flight attendants ask customers to put on their oxygen masks before helping others, teachers must take care of themselves before they can help their students.

These challenges plus the influence of Covid-19 made this a high-risk endeavor, but one that has broad impacts now that this project is successful. This project advanced understanding in the development of school behavioral health, demonstrated how technical and behavioral research with natural language processing and artificial intelligence can be combined to produce a cost-effective system for improving adolescent mental health outcomes.

A 9-month pilot study at a rural middle school was significant in creating a transformative reThinkIt! MVP/Version 1 where Minty began its training to use Ai to engage adolescents efficiently and effectively for early detection of mental health issues such as stress, anxiety and depression. Minty helped these middle school administrators resolve kids' complex mental healthcare needs by reducing the time it takes to solve their problems.

Specifically, our Phase I behavioral research informed us that students and school staff benefited from reThinkIt! MVP/V1: 52% say it helps me communicate better with my teachers, 40% report reThinkIt! calms them down, 40% report reThinkIt! helps me feel like it's okay to talk about things that are upsetting me and 73% are very/somewhat likely to continue using reThinkIt!. Future improvements, such as LiveChat for Teachers and Students and more testing of the Alert System and the Smart Minty chatbot show that added features create a fully functioning reThinkIt! that addresses long-term mental well-being in school districts across the United States.

In closing, let us briefly share our findings about US rural schools who are in significant distress and where the youth mental health crisis is more evident. Re-engagement post-Covid has been especially challenging for rural students who live far from their school buildings. Many of these challenges, result in discipline management challenges which reThinkIt! is adept at helping schools handle. Future research can provide not only an improved solution for early detection of mental illness in our rural middle schools, but also can support teachers' mental well-being to facilitate teacher retention.


Last Modified: 09/21/2023
Modified by: Beth Carls

Image
  • Minty is an intelligent chatbot companion to help students navigate their emotions
    Amy Looper
    Copyrighted
    Beth Carls
    Love, Minty
